awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Health Monitoring and System Identification of Complex Mechanical Systems Using Fractional-Order Calculus Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Inspection and maintenance are significant cost drivers to manage and preserve the quality of our nation's transportation systems and infrastructure. Current strategies are based on preventive approaches that do not consider the actual real-time status of a specific structural component. In these approaches, the systems are subject to routine inspections and replacement of components that are scheduled a priori based on a combination of empirical data and numerical predictions of the estimated life. Such approaches are sub-optimal because they may lead to replacement of fully-functional components, on the one  hand, and may miss rapidly deteriorating conditions between scheduled inspections, on the other. This research will develop new methods to address both shortcomings by investigating new modeling and monitoring techniques particularly suited and applicable to modern, complex systems.  To enable this condition-based monitoring approach better theoretical and numerical models are needed to simulate the dynamic behavior of complex mechanical systems as well as to produce metrics capable of tracking their status in real-time. This award supports fundamental research to develop mathematical and computational models based on fractional calculus. The methods resulting from this research will be highly useful in application that use imaging and remote sensing in structural, geological, and biological media. The educational part of this project will feature, among its different components, the development of a new course to introduce engineering students to fractional calculus and its applications to modeling of engineering systems.

This research will involve a systematic study to determine how fractional-order differential equations will enhance the state-of-the-art in system identification and monitoring. Fractional-order models are a new and useful tool for modeling of complex engineering systems, however they are not yet common in engineering. Their application to structural health monitoring will provide a substantially new approach for damage detection and diagnostics, it will introduce the system order as a new parameter for system assessment, and it will provide highly mathematically structured and concise descriptions of the dynamics of complex systems.  More specifically, this work will (1) determine the effect of structural damage on the fractional order of the host system and develop methodologies to account for its impact on the underlying governing equations; (2) use fractional approaches to achieve efficient order reduction, sub-structuring, and inverse problem solutions; (3) develop fractional models for system identification based on purely experimental data; and (4) develop testbeds for experimental validation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A common feature of modern engineering systems is increased integration and interoperability. Systems that used to operate independently are increasingly operating in a coordinated manner. A good example is automobile traffic. Until recently, automobiles were controlled entirely by the driver in it, generally following the traffic rules. Currently automobiles have adaptive cruise control where they can sense a vehicle ahead and slow down or speed up accordingly. Hence, if a whole line of vehicles have this feature, the way they are automatically controlled is no longer independent. In the future, vehicles will have comprehensive communications systems where they will send an receive information between themselves and other vehicles as well as between themselves and infrastructure, such as traffic lights.

For example, enormous savings will result from a traffic signal communicating to approaching vehicles when the signal will change, enabling the vehicles to travel at the optimal speed to avoid wasteful braking, etc. Furthermore, such communication will enable vehicles to platoon so that groups of them pass through an intersection without having to slow. Even more simply, in the middle of the night with no other traffic on the road, if a vehicle can communicate to a signal that it is approaching, the signal can change accordingly.

A major challenge to this vision, in addition to the infrastructure cost, is that the vehicles, which formerly were considered independent, are now part of a very large system which must be designed, modeled and controlled as one very large system, as opposed to a collection of simpler, independent systems. Almost all engineering tools have trouble dealing with very large systems, and new approaches to modeling and controlling such systems is needed.

This project considered using an old mathematical tool, fractional calculus, in a new way. Fractional calculus is not used extensively currently in engineering; however, the fact that it naturally can handle nonlocal effects makes it a good candidate to address some of the challenges faced by increasingly integrated systems. This project specifically developed tools based on fractional calculus to model very large scale self-similar systems, such as a system of vehicles which are nearly identical. It also developed tools to identify if there are damaged components, such as a vehicle that is not operating properly. These results and tools should help the progress of increasingly integrated systems, which should bring about greatly increased efficiency with corresponding human, economic, environmental, and sustainability benefits.
